title: Thursday, 26th October, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:02 am
PM11:02am

Morning

PM11:02am

Sorry a bit late today

PM11:02am

No excuse

11:02 am
PM11:03am

Now, I don't want to share another picture of Xi

PM11:03am

But you should read this

PM11:03am

https://www.ft.com...-beba-5521c713abf4

11:03 am
PM11:03am

On United Front

PM11:03am

And Chinese softpower

PM11:03am

It's very good

11:04 am
PM11:04am

Instead, as a pic, you can have a tweet

PM11:04am

https://twitter.com/chigrl/status/923444721237807104

PM11:04am

Suppose we must share some ECB grey as well

11:04 am
PM11:05am

How about UBS

PM11:05am

ECB to cut monthly purchases to €30bn, with a commitment for 9 monthsWe expect the ECB to announce next week (26 October) that it will cut its monthly asset purchases from €60bn to €30bn as of January, with a commitment for nine months, i.e. until end-September 2018. We think the ECB will leave open whether it will extend QE after September and hint that this decision will be taken in a data-dependent fashion, closer to the time. We believe the ECB will maintain a QE easing bias, indicating that it will stand ready to scale up QE again in the event of negative shocks. The ECB will likely reiterate that, in addition to the monthly asset purchases, maturing securities of its QE portfolio will be reinvested for the foreseeable future, and stress their quantitative significance. As part of its interest rate forward guidance, the ECB is likely to reiterate that key interest rates are likely to stay at current levels "for an extended period of time, and well past" the end of QE. We think the Bank will once again commit to maintaining a "very substantial degree of monetary accommodation" in order to bring inflation back to the target

PM11:05am

QE to end after Q3-2018, first rate hikes as of 2019, liquidity to stay abundantAccording to our base case scenario, the ECB will bring QE to a close by end-Sept, but we acknowledge the "risk" of a moderate QE extension during Q4 2018. In line with the ECB's guidance, we expect key interest rates to be hiked only after the end of QE, most likely as of 2019. Overall liquidity conditions are likely to stay accommodative. Our base case scenario for tapering (€30bn over 9 months) marks a change from our previous call, which centred on a stepwise reduction in QE over 6-9 months

11:05 am
PM11:06am

And that will do on that

PM11:06am

Cos I'm bored of the subject

undefined
11:06 am
PM11:06am

What do you reckon Bryce/ Get stuck into Barclays?

BE11:07am

I guess we can.

BE11:07am

It's a miss. BarCap sucks.

11:07 am
Barclays PLC (BARC:LSE): Last: 184.50, down 12.5 (-6.35%), High: 190.90, Low: 182.95, Volume: 63.76m
PM11:07am

It's a huge miss

BE11:08am

And cost guidance is stepped up

11:08 am
BE11:08am

Consensus is coming down about 5% on that.

PM11:08am

The investment bank has seen business collapse

BE11:09am

To be clear, there's also a one-off hit from the sale of the US card book in the first quarter

11:09 am
BE11:09am

Which makes the headline number out by about 23% vs consensus.

BE11:10am

Underlying though, it's still a 13% miss.

BE11:10am

And, yeah, it's IB.

11:10 am
BE11:10am

Here's Goldman to summarise.

PM11:10am

Ah, ok, but you'd think the credit card hit would have been in analysts figs

PM11:10am

Sorry, go with Goldman

11:10 am
BE11:11am

Yeah, sale was known but loss was unexpected. Which I guess means it wasn't flagged properly by the IR department.

BE11:11am

IB revenues down 23% (yoy and in USD). FICC was down 34% yoy, with credit down 22% owing to lower flow revenues and macro down 40% driven by lower income in rates and also the re-integration of non-core) - excluding the reintegration of non-core, FICC would be down 29%. Equities was down 24% yoy, driven by lower trading income in derivatives and cash. All in, the IB result is weaker compared to US peers (Equities flat, FICC -22%, IBD +8%, Total -9%).

BE11:11am

Revised targets: Two major changes: (1) The company now provides a timeline for medium term guidance: 10% ROTE in 2020 and C/I of below 60% in 2019.
(2) Revised cost guidance: (i) £14.2-14.3bn for 2017 - this compares to latest consensus at £13.9bn - we believe the increase is attributable to higher restructuring costs (ring-fence) and investments; (ii) 2019: £13.6-13.9bn vs consensus at £13.6bn. Lastly, unchanged capital guidance (no change in Pillar 2A),

11:12 am
BE11:12am

And UBS, to emphasise that the numbers are a bloody mess.

PM11:12am

The actual q3 statement is here btw https://www.invest...1710260700046455U/

BE11:13am

Group results are heavily distorted by disposal and litigation costs. Time series divisional analysis is not feasible given the re-incorporation of non-core assets into the ongoing divisions in 3Q without restated historic figures. Overall however Barclays sees the 3Q17 result as an 8% miss to adj. consensus, adding back card disposal impairments (£168m) and FERC settlement costs (£75m). Barclays UK is broadly in line with forecasts
with the miss driven by weak income in Markets – revenues down 31%, 25% ex Non-Core impacts - with equity derivatives notably disappointing. CET1 at 13.1% was 20bps below consensus, 8bps of which is driven by another credit model update, this one relating to small corporate and business banking. TNAV of 281p was in line with UBSe.

11:13 am
PM11:13am

And the ring fence stuff here https://www.invest...1710260700066490U/

BE11:13am

Barclays has given new cost and ROTE targets aiming for a ROTE of greater than 9% in 2019 and greater than 10% in 2020. Hard cost figures and target years are a welcome improvement in clarity but we think the implied revenue growth could be a challenge for many to accept. The 2019 target assumes a cost/income ratio below 60%. Taking 58% as a base implies a need to grow consensus revenues by 11% over two years and reduce costs by 4% for pre-provision profit 8% higher than 2019 consensus forecasts and up 34% compared with current 2017 consensus. Even then, 2019 bad debts and non-controlling interest charges would need to outperform market expectations we think to get to the 9% target the firm is aiming to deliver on a 13% assumed CET1. Given the challenge LBG had yesterday in convincing the market that CET1 of 13.5% was sufficient we think this could be a challenge for Barclays also today.

BE11:14am

We expect consensus income forecasts to fall today based on the weak 3Q17 number.
Guided FY17 costs are £400m higher than market expectations with the increase
apparently driven by restructuring. With 3Q17 Markets revenues having missed we
think investors might be sceptical about the target revenue growth and high implied
assumed return on investment. Today's 9.30am conference call [...] looks set to be critical in laying out the basis for the planned revenue uplift. We have Barclays trading at 0.67x TNAV and 9.1x 2018E EPS. Given weaker-than-expected results and the reliance on revenue growth in the plan we would expect the share to come under pressure today.

11:15 am
BE11:15am

Or, much more briefly, from Ian Gordon at Investec.

BE11:15am

We think new ROTE targets (greater than 9% in 2019 and greater than 10% in 2020) appear aspirational. The costs appear reasonable; the implicit revenue targets less so.

BE11:15am

Q3 performance was poor, albeit trading on 0.7x Q3 2017 tNAV (281p) we do not believe the market is pricing in that much “hope”. Our Buy rec, existing 235p target price and forecasts are all under review.

11:16 am
PM11:16am

That Buy recommendation looks to be history

BE11:17am

Ditto Merrill.

BE11:17am

3Q has missed on P+L and Balance Sheet. Lower 3Q income and higher near term cost guidance will pressure 2017 consensus EPS. New targets anchor the 10% ROTE target to 2020. New cost guidance for 2019 shows that the improvement is all about revenues. The IB performed poorly vs US peers and sets a low bar for 2018. Worse before it gets better, we maintain U/P.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

And that's probably enough Barclays.

undefined
PM11:18am

There's a few trading statements around today

11:18 am
BE11:19am

There are, though it's sort of quiet corporate wise for a Thursday.

BE11:19am

What's caught your eye?

BE11:20am

....... should I assume from that long pause that the answer is "not much"?

11:20 am
BE11:21am

I mean, there's Inbev, as mentioned on the right, which is a familiar sort of story.

BE11:21am

Sales miss.

BE11:21am

Costs come out to compensate.

11:21 am
BE11:22am

Organic EBITDA +13% vs the +15% expected.

BE11:22am

But you still get an EPS of $1.31, versus $1.28 consensus, which I guess demonstrates the 3G model as well as anything can .....

BE11:23am

$336m of incremental synergies, which is a lot of brewery workers given the tin tack.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

And synergy guidance goes to $3.2bn from $2.8bn over the next three years.

BE11:24am

Here's Mirabaud to summarise all the moving parts here.

BE11:24am

Numerous technical effects make for a noisy set of results but, in the round, we are minded to view the numbers in a positive light. Despite revenue growth coming in below expectations (+3.6% vs. consensus +5%), EBITDA is only slightly below consensus (+13.8% vs. +15%). On an absolute basis, EBIT is in line and EPS has come in 3% ahead. Management have also raised the SABMiller cost synergy guidance another $400m to $3.2bn, which should support estimates.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

The key update is that management have found an additional $400m of cost synergies, taking the total to $3.2bn. Management continue to make good progress on realising the synergy potential, delivering another $336m of savings this quarter. Usefully, management also now expect the effective tax rate for the year to be at the lower end of the 22-24% range.

BE11:25am

More broadly, the return to profit growth in Brazil is an important development and removes a significant headwind from AB InBev’s growth trajectory. However, the continued market share declines in the US means that will remain an area of concern. The silver lining is that on a sequential basis AB InBev’s market share performance has improved from minus 100bps in Q2 to minus 80 bps this quarter. Furthermore, monthly IRI data suggests Bud Light’s market share also improved sequentially through the quarter, which suggests Q4 should show further improvement. Numerous technical factors make this is a difficult quarter to draw firm conclusions. Certainly in light of the shipment phasing issue in the USA, the headline miss at the organic revenue growth line is not a true reflection of trend. Ultimately, we take the view that $400m of additional cost synergies and slightly lowered tax rate guidance should support consensus earnings expectations.

PM11:26am

So ABI now has over a fifth of the global beer market.

11:26 am
BE11:26am

Okay, so SABMiller wasn't the most lean of companies. I've fuzzy memories of several lunches at the Savoy serving as evidence of that.

BE11:26am

But $3.2bn is an extraordinary amount of costs to cut.

PM11:27am

Actually no, it's 30%

11:27 am
BE11:27am

Increasingly difficult to measure market share in the beer market because of the localisation trend, of course.

BE11:28am

"Craft" is now about 10% of the total, if I remember correctly.

BE11:28am

Anyway, that's enough beer as well.

11:28 am
PM11:28am

Hmm, maybe

undefined
BE11:29am

Bit of DPL maybe?

11:28 am
PM11:29am

why not

BE11:29am

Because somehow this week, we've failed to mention yet another bloody awful housing policy ...

BE11:29am

Another bit of tinkering around with demand rather than supply.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

https://www.ft.com...-9bfb-4a9c83ffa852

BE11:29am

Philip Hammond, the chancellor, has denied that the government is about to borrow £50bn to invest in housing at next month’s Budget, but is understood to be mulling stamp duty reforms that could help first-time home buyers at the expense of landlords.

BE11:30am

The chancellor is understood to favour less costly interventions in the housing market, such as a cut in stamp duty for first-time buyers, which could be funded by an increase in the transaction tax for landlords.
Treasury officials see the possible move as a way for the government to demonstrate to young people that it understands their concerns about “intergenerational fairness”.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

The bright side here is that, unlike Help-To-Bung, it's not tinkering with demand in any meaningful way.

BE11:30am

Credit Suisse runs the numbers.

BE11:30am

Scrapping of stamp duty for first time buyers is unlikely to cause a large pick up in transactions: Our analysis finds that stamp duty accounts for just 10% (London) and 4% (UK) of the total upfront costs incurred when purchasing a first home. Eliminating FtB stamp duty would reduce the typical saving period from 4.6 years to 4.2 years in London and from 1.8 years to 1.7 years in UK (ex. London). Thus, we conclude that scrapping of stamp duty for first time buyers (FtBs) will be less impactful to transaction volumes than many think.

11:02 am
PM11:02am

Welcome to Markets Live

BE11:31am

Historically, transactions have not picked-up after FtB tax incentives: Over the past 25 years there have been three stamp duty holidays/relief for FtBs. We find that housing transactions in both London and England have exhibited no clear increase after the introduction of the tax break on both a 6, 12 and 18 month view.

BE11:31am

So the detail there is that in March 2005, the 0% stamp duty cutoff was increased to £120k from £60k.

11:31 am
BE11:31am

In September 2008 the cutoff moved to £120k, and in April 2010 it went to £250k for first-time buyers alone.

BE11:31am

And each time, absolutely nothing happened.

BE11:31am

11:31 am
BE11:32am

So, according to CS, here's what the government should be doing.

BE11:32am

Removing stamp duty for first time movers could be better for transaction growth: The property deposit is not the most significant hurdle for first time movers because the equity gained from the first property is used to fund the deposit needed for the second home. Over the past five years, the average equity made by first time buyers on their property is £164k in London and £69k in UK (ex.London). Consequently, stamp duty is the largest frictional cost facing first time movers and thus we believe scrapping it for this housing demographic would be greater stimulant for housing transactions.

BE11:32am

But of course, a tax break for movers wouldn't do much for the housebuilders ....

11:32 am
BE11:33am

... who (as we keep saying) have jacked up prices in lockstep with the HTB subsidy.

BE11:33am

As per this Morgan Stanley note from last week, while I was on a holiday from ranting about HTB ....

BE11:34am

11:33 am
BE11:34am

... "new build house prices have now outstripped secondhand by 15% since the start of Help to Buy in 2013," says MOST.

BE11:34am

While the trend is very positive for housebuilders' earnings near term, at some point the 'Help to Buy premium' will be ‘priced in’, and we are now c.5% points away from the level at which new build prices have diverged by the full amount of the government's equity loan (20% of house price across England). This is significant because, all else equal, it means new build price growth cannot continue to outpace the wider secondhand market for much longer at current rates.

BE11:34am

Bloody. Awful. Policy.

11:34 am
Taylor Wimpey PLC (TW.:LSE): Last: 206.80, up 1.7 (+0.83%), High: 207.10, Low: 205.50, Volume: 3.99m
Barratt Developments PLC (BDEV:LSE): Last: 665.00, down 33.5 (-4.80%), High: 670.00, Low: 660.00, Volume: 2.00m
BE11:35am

(Which is ex div)

11:35 am
Berkeley Group Holdings PLC (BKG:LSE): Last: 3,943, down 35 (-0.88%), High: 3,996, Low: 3,931, Volume: 202.32k
BE11:35am

Etc.

undefined
11:35 am
PM11:36am

V interesting

BE11:36am

Moving over to requests ...............

BE11:37am

GSK noted. Still falling.

11:36 am
GlaxoSmithKline PLC (GSK:LSE): Last: 1,406, down 22.63 (-1.58%), High: 1,429, Low: 1,406, Volume: 7.53m
BE11:38am

Yesterday's drop was blamed on various things, but primarily the guarded commitment to the divi in combination with an explicit expression of interest for that bit of Pfizer.

BE11:38am

Underlying, though, the numbers were pretty bad.

11:39 am
BE11:39am

There was an impression that R&D spend was coming down to save the bottom line, and that the HIV franchise in particular wasn't doing as well as expected.

BE11:40am

This morning, Merrill downgrades, though I only have the briefest of summaries to their thinking.

BE11:40am

Although GSK's valuation is not demanding, (PE 13.7x 19E) we see growing uncertainties as likely to cap PE recovery into 2018. Key concerns: 18E margin pressure and cons EPS est. cuts; Rising threat to HIV from Rx trends; Renewed dividend uncertainty.

11:40 am
BE11:40am

Morgan Stanley fills out the argument rather more.

BE11:41am

Should investors get prepared for a dividend cut post 2018 (and dilutive deal)?
Questions on the call mainly focused on pricing pressure in respiratory, intensifying competition in HIV, headwinds in Consumer and more importantly capital allocation and we found GSK's responses not as reassuring as we would have hoped. Management confirmed its interest in Pfizer’s consumer unit and declined to comment on dividend stability beyond 2018 and did not "draw a red line" as the question was asked during the call. We expect this, along with a lack of meaningful progress in the pipeline and R&D restructuring, will not be helpful in reassuring investors. On the latter, we flag the creation of three "groups" primarily focused on early stage activities in domains outside of the four core areas defined at HY17 results. We struggle to see the value creation model, particularly for the third group called "Global health discovery" exploring "diseases of the developing world and other areas of global health", which would potentially lock R&D costs in the P&L.

PM11:42am

back (hopefully)

11:42 am
BE11:42am

Management confirmed the stability of the dividend at 80p in 2018, but declined to comment beyond that point, saying it would be 'premature' to do so. We believe that the bear case of a potential dividend cut is again a credible option, notably in the context of the CEO's remarks that they are looking at Pfizer’s consumer unit. GSK explained that they are systematically looking at any asset that potentially strengthens their OTC power brands, and they would potentially consider a structured deal with their JV. While they also said it is premature to discuss if and how such a move could be possible, we flag that the potential acquisition price of USD14-25bn [...] would weigh heavily on GSK's balance sheet, which is already under pressure: 1.7x net debt to EBITDA in 2018e, potentially increasing to above 3x, or even more adding the potential stake of Novartis if GSK were to exercise their put option in March 2018.

BE11:43am

The "divi or growth" question is going to be the one facing GSK investors for the next year or so, I guess.

BE11:44am

Natixis reckons they should choose growth.

11:44 am
PM11:44am

Indeed

BE11:44am

We would like to see GSK diversify its sources of growth, either by buying up drugs under licence or by taking over companies. GSK has few major product launches ongoing, unlike Sanofi, Novo and Roche. Shingrix (shingles vaccine), which has just been approved, will certainly become a blockbuster, and Trelegy (triple combination) is a growth relay for the respiratory franchise, but the group acknowledges that these drugs will ramp up only gradually. Given its current portfolio, we think the group is doomed to grow more slowly than the sector average.

BE11:44am

In this context, a pay-out rate of 71% seems high to us. Especially as GSK is already in a less favourable financial position than its peers, with its debt expected at £13.8bn at end-2017 (1.4x EBITDA) and its liabilities sizeable (Novartis put option on its stake in the OTC division for £8.2bn, deferred payments of £5.9bn). Buying Pfizer Consumer would add $12/15bn to the debt pile in exchange for $3.4bn of sales revenue. The group would struggle to go ahead with such a deal while also buying Novartis’ stake in its own OTC division (unless Novartis prefers to participate in the deal).

11:45 am
BE11:45am

.... however, you have the market already pricing in divi cuts from BT -- https://www.ft.com...-9bfb-4a9c83ffa852 -- and probably from Centrica as well.

BE11:46am

And divis aren't arriving as fast as expected from the re-privatised banks.

BE11:46am

Tricky to be an income investor right now.

11:46 am
undefined
BE11:46am

ROTR -- apologies if it appears your comments are disappearing into the ether .....

PM11:47am

We have issues

11:47 am
BE11:47am

Yup .... we have an automatic comment screening system that seems to be a bit hyperactive today, and it's too much of a faff to fix while also typing this stuff.

PM11:47am

I've been clicking a few through in the back end, but it's not ideal

BE11:48am

We see what you're saying, even if you don't. Please be assured that your call is important to us.

11:48 am
BE11:48am

Anyway, what else?

BE11:48am

Liberum's gone negative on Glencore .....

Glencore PLC (GLEN:LSE): Last: 379.95, up 3.65 (+0.97%), High: 380.50, Low: 373.10, Volume: 8.68m
11:48 am
PM11:49am

Why?

BE11:49am

Coal, mostly.

BE11:49am

Liberum calls are always notable on Glencore because they helped floated it, way back in the day, though it's gone through several team rejigs since.

11:50 am
BE11:50am

This is Ben Davis, who's always very readable.

BE11:50am

The proposed cuts to domestic Chinese industry over the winter heating season are dramatic and have far reaching consequences for the mining equities. The impacts on low grade iron ore and coking coal demand from the steel cuts have been widely commentated on (see Download Supply Reforming ), but it is possible seaborne thermal coal imports will be hit as hard. The cuts in energy intensive industries that consumed thermal coal both directly and indirectly could see Chinese demand negatively impacted by 160mtpa during mid November to mid March. If the brunt of this cut was felt through seaborne demand (rather than a weaker low quality domestic supply or restocking activity), then in theory imports could drop close to zero. Whilst this is the extreme bear case scenario, thermal coal is not as well supported as we had previously expected and assume prices to fall to $75/t from currently $95/t by year end.

BE11:50am

The increased downside risk in thermal, combined with the lack of fundamental support for the recent rally in copper and the turning of our short term demand indicators, we downgrade Glencore to a SELL and a price target £3.00 (prev Hold, £2.85) following recent out performance. Glencore remains on a relative basis our top pick of the majors, given its lack of exposure to steel making materials.

11:51 am
BE11:51am

.... And the underlying stuff on air pollution's interesting here.

BE11:52am

The Chinese Government are very focused on cutting pollution over the winter heating season given the hazardous levels of particulate matter in the air around Beijing and its neighbouring cities. A combination of the weather, industrial activities and domestic heating causes particulate matter of 2.5 microns to rise rapidly between mid-November and mid- March. Unlike GDP estimates, which can be manipulated to meet targets, pollution levels are easily observable by independent bodies like the U.S. Embassy and thus the Government will be at pains to meet their targets as evidence of progress to a clean, healthy society.

BE11:52am

11:52 am
BE11:53am

During the winter heating season around 300mt coal are burnt in China and there is a push for a move to electricity or gas. Given that 23% of the population are in the five affected provinces and maybe 50% of coal use is cut (some cities reporting 90% consumption cuts), some 35mt of coal energy would have to be replaced. In theory if it was wholly replaced by electricity this would demand an extra 5% from the system, entirely offsetting the industrial cuts. However given that the focus is cutting pollution, we would expect the majority to be replaced by cleaner gas demand.

PM11:53am

that is interesting

BE11:53am

And good, basically. Though not for Glencore.

11:53 am
undefined
BE11:54am

(@Lefevre: what's changed in the past decade that means they wan't new houses so much more than in the previous 2000 years?)

BE11:55am

......... still on mining, I guess we should mention Sirius.

11:55 am
Sirius Minerals PLC (SXX:LSE): Last: 27.56, up 1.24 (+4.71%), High: 28.50, Low: 26.59, Volume: 20.82m
BE11:56am

.... which I know is of interest to some people on the right.

BE11:57am

So. They've signed up PT Chemical Indonesia as a buyer of 750ktpa of dirt.

11:57 am
BE11:57am

PT's part of the Singapore-listed Wilmar Group, which is about $16bn market cap so can be seen as a pretty respectable customer.

BE11:58am

Initial seven year deal, with three year extension at Wilmar's discretion.

BE11:59am

Along with an option to raise minimum volumes to 1Mtpa .... price is "“calculated using a formula linked to the market price of certain nutrients contained in POLY4” whatever that means.

11:59 am
PM12:00pm

Blimey

BE12:00pm

First customer deal announced by Sirius since August 15, and its third biggest by tonnage.

BE12:00pm

Here's JP Morgan, which like this thing.

12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

We see this announcement as a material positive development for SXX for a number of reasons. Firstly, it incrementally de-risks the 100% debt-funded Stage 2 financing given “firm” commitments are expected by H2’18. As we have written about previously (here), we had increasingly seen this as the project’s critical path. Furthermore, partnering with a “blue chip” customer such as Wilmar serves the dual purpose of (i) vindicating the efficacy of POLY4, which should help to position it as a viable disruptor in the fertiliser segment, and (ii) implicitly lends credibility to SXX & the project it is developing in North Yorkshire. Coupled with successful Stage 1 funding (Nov’16), we believe this could ultimately have positive implications on future commercial discussions. We remain Overweight.

BE12:01pm

Fairly sure they're house.

BE12:01pm

Our positive investment thesis is based on: (i) SXX being the cheapest stock within our EMEA mining coverage, with shares trading less than 0.2x P/NPV; (ii) immediate development risks abating following the material (~$1.1bn) capital raising in late 2016 & approvals which permit production up to 13Mtpa; (iii) projects’ geological & geographical setting underpin attractive economics (JPM ~17% IRR) which are resilient even under considerably worse assumptions; and (iv) leverage to the fertiliser market which has favourable late cycle dynamics associated with population growth & higher urbanisation.

12:02 pm
BE12:02pm

Oh, and if you want a trip to a damp field in Yorkshire next month to look at some mud, JPM has a trip to the mine set up for November 17.

BE12:02pm

"Places are limited", they warn, so get in quick.

PM12:02pm

Excellent

12:03 pm
undefined
PM12:03pm

Think we are done. Thanks for all that Bryce

PM12:03pm

Back tomorrow at 11am sharp.

12:03 pm
PM12:04pm

Bye

BE11:31am
